description: From Middle English bitrouthen, bitreuthen, from treuthe (“truth”), from Old English trēowþe (“truth, pledge, troth”). Equivalent to be- +‎ troth.

verbs.description: betroth (third-person singular simple present betroths, present participle betrothing, simple past betrothed, past participle betrothed or betrothen)

entries.meaning: To promise to give in marriage.
examples: He betrothed his daughter to a distant relative.

entries.meaning: To promise to take (as a future spouse); to plight one's troth to.
